Award.AwardTitle: Search Based Software Engineering: Building a North American Community

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This travel grant assists in the formation of a new community around Search-Based Software Engineering by funding travel for students to a new symposium. Search-based software engineering (SBSE) views software engineering problems as optimization problems utilizing metaheuristic techniques to discover near optimal solutions. The symposium will bring together researchers (and their students) from many different areas of Software Engineering. The travel support will enable students to participate and learn from others in the field and advance their research.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the symposium was to bring together the growing North American search based software engineering (NasBASE, http://www.nasbase.org/) community in a welcoming forum for discussion and dissemination, and to sustain the recent flourishing of interest in the field. The venue for NasBASE 2015 was the Detroit metro area.

We invited papers that address problems in the software engineering domain through the use of heuristic search techniques. We particularly encouraged papers demonstrating novel search strategies or the application of SBSE techniques to new problems in software engineering. 

In addition to the regular technical research papers, we also invited papers for a special PhD student track that provided a venue for students to present their work and receive feedback from senior members of the SBSE research community. PhD papers included thesis plans, proposed research, as well as partial or complete SBSE research results already obtained. Most of the students participated in this session received already an NSF travel support.

We also orgnized tutorials about basic concepts of SBSE (introduction to SBSE for new researchers in the field or graduate students to join the SBSE community) and the future of SBSE, and possible funding opportunities/projects. The tutorials session supported also collaborative efforts to form teams that might submit large collaborative SBSE proposals for funding. 

We offered several travel awards for graduate students to attend NasBASE2015, with preference to target under-represented groups. For example, several blind students and also womens were selected for the travel support. 


Last Modified: 09/28/2015
Modified by: Marouane Kessentini
